Title: Kerala Police Mobile App (POL-APP)
Content: The Kerala Police has introduced a citizen-centric mobile application named POL-APP, developed by TCS. The app offers 27 advanced services categorized under Citizen Services, Women and Child Related Services, Citizen Safety Services, Information Services, Report to Us, and Rate Our Services. Features include locating the nearest police station with navigation, accessing contact details of police offices and officers, downloading e-FIRs, making payments to the treasury, checking passport verification status, registering senior citizens for Janamaithry services, receiving push notifications, accessing social media feeds, playing the Traffic Guru game, searching services, using the tourist guide, viewing helpline numbers, gaining cyber awareness, and accessing important website links.

Title: Watch and Ward
Content:
Watch and Ward unit is the security wing of the State Legislature. The personnel of the Watch & Ward unit are appointed in the Legislature Secretariat on deputation basis from the State Police Department. They work under the general directions and control of the Hon'ble Speaker and the Secretary to Legislature. The Chief Marshal is the head of Watch and Ward unit, who is assisted by one Additional Chief Marshal, 4 Marshals, 10 Sergeants, 86 Sergeant Assistants and 6 Woman Sergeant Assistants.

The Marshals Sergeants and Sergeant Assistants will be in White Uniform issued to them during the time of duty in the Legislature Secretariat and in the Legislature Hostel. Normally Chief Marshal is an officer in the Rank of Superintendent of Police/Commandant of Police. Additional Chief Marshal is in the Rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police/Assistant Commandant Marshal, Sergeant, Sergeant Assistant/Woman Sergeant in the Rank of Sub Inspector, Senior Civil Police Officer, Civil Police Officer respectively. Watch & Ward handles security and safety of Legislature Complex including MLAs Hostel. They also provide private security to Hon'ble Speaker and Hon'ble Deputy Speaker in the Assembly premises.

Title: Governance of Kerala Police

Title: Right to Information (RTI) Online Filing Facility - Kerala Police
Content: The Kerala Police provides an online facility for filing applications under the Right to Information (RTI) Act. Applicants can submit their requests using the application formats available on the website via email. The mode of payment of fees, such as Postal Order or Money Order, must be specified in the online application. The requested information will be provided by the State Public Information Officer (SPIO) only after receiving the formal application along with the required fee. Application forms for obtaining information under the RTI Act 2005 are available for download in both Malayalam and English languages in PDF and DOC formats. Additionally, application forms to appeal before the Appellate Authority are also available for download in both languages and formats. The portal was last updated on Thursday, 7th August 2025.

Title: Nilambur Detachment Camp of KAP II Battalion
Content: Kerala Armed Police - II Battalion operates a detachment camp at Nilambur in Malappuram District. Located near the Nilambur Forest Division and along the banks of the River Chaliyar, this camp originally functioned as a sub-camp of the Malabar Special Police. Land for the camp was leased by the Nilambur Forest Division via Order No. 1075/25 issued by the erstwhile Madras State in 1925. After the formation of KAP II Battalion in 1976, the Malabar Special Police handed over the camp to KAP II for continued operation. The total proposed area of the camp is approximately 8.66 hectares (21.4 acres). A new administrative block was constructed and commissioned on 29 June 2012, housing offices including those of the Commandant, Deputy Commandant, Assistant Commandants (Adjutant and Quartermaster), Wing Officers, Company Commanders, and the Battalion Office.

Title: Police in Malabar Region
Content: Prior to Tipu Sultan's occupation, Malabar was administered by Naduvazhis and Desavazhis using local chieftains. In the early 18th century, a primitive police force called 'Kolkars' maintained order. After Tipu's invasion, chaos ensued due to displaced rulers. Upon British takeover in 1810, Captain Watts trained 500 Armed Policemen who replaced existing forces. An additional 1600 Kolkars were later added. In 1816, a new system assigned village-level policing to Adhikaris, taluk-level to Tahasildars, and city-level to Police Amins—all under District Magistrates. Sepoys performed dual revenue and police roles. To address systemic flaws, military officers were appointed alongside a native police force consisting of 31 officers, 150 Sepoys, and 2 buglers. In 1921, Mr. Hitchcock established the Malabar Special Police modeled on the British Army, becoming its first Commandant. By 1932, it expanded to 16 companies.

Title: Functions of Single Digit Finger Print Bureaux
Content: The Single Digit Finger Print Bureaux perform the following functions: conducting scene-of-crime inspections upon request by concerned Station House Officers (SHOs); collecting evidence and chance prints; identifying chance prints as those of culprits; providing expert opinions in court; and maintaining records of culprits within their respective districts.

Title: Coastal Police
Content: The Coastal Police Stations are being set up as part of a nation-wide initiative to enhance security along the coastal areas in the background of the Mumbai terror attack. The basic objective of establishing Coastal Police Stations, in various Coastal States and Union Territories is to overcome the limitations of the state Police in terms of needed infrastructure and skilled manpower to exercise their policing jurisdiction effectively in the Territorial Waters (ie. upto 12 nautical miles from the shore). Currently, it is functioning as a three-tier coastal security ring all along the coast ie, Indian Navy, Indian Coast Guard (ICG) and Coastal Police. The Indian Navy is patrolling along International Maritime Boundary Line (IMBL), while the ICG is mandated to carry out patrolling and surveillance up to the Exclusive Economic Zone of India (EEZ) (ie. upto 200 nautical miles from the shore) and the State Coastal Police performs boat patrolling in the shallow coastal area. The first Coastal Police Station was started at Neendakara in Kollam District in 2009, 18 Coastal Police stations have been setup along the length of Kerala Coast running to 596 KM comprised in 9 Coastal Districts. They are located at Poovar (Thiruvananthapuram Rural District) Vizhinjam (Thiruvananthapuram City District), Anjuthengu (Thiruvananthapuram Rural District), Neendakara (Kollam District), Thottapally (Alappuzha District), Arthungal (Alappuzha District), Fort Kochi (Ernakulam District), Azhikkode (Thrissur Rural District), Munakakadavu (Thrissur City District), Ponnani (Malappuram District), Beypore (Kozhikode City District), Elathur (Kozhikode City District), Vadakara (Kozhikode Rural District), Azheekkal (Kannur District), Thalassery (Kannur District), Bekal (Kasargode District), Thrikkaripur (Kasargode District) and Kumbala (Kasargode District).

Title: Armed Police Battalions of Kerala Police
Content: The Armed Police Battalions serve as a reserve force to be deployed whenever and wherever the district police falls short of manpower in the maintenance of law and order. Administratively, the armed police battalions serve as the feeder service for subsequent transfer to the district police. Organizationally, they are maintained on the pattern of infantry battalions found anywhere in the world. There are eleven battalions with a total strength of about 6,755 located at different places in the state. These include: 1. Ist Kerala Armed Police - KAP-I (Thrissur/Trichur), 2. Vth Kerala Armed Police - KAP-V (Kuttikanam), 6. Special Armed Police - SAP (Thiruvananthapuram), 7. Malabar Special Police - MSP (Malappuram), 8. Rapid Response and Rescue Force - RRRF (Pandikkad), 9. India Reserve Battalion - IRBn (Thrissur), 10. State Industrial Security Force - SISF (Thiruvananthapuram), 11. Armed Women Police Battalion. Title: Janamaithri Suraksha Project
Content: The Janamaithri Suraksha Project of Kerala Police is a pioneering initiative aimed at bridging the gap between the police and the public by involving citizens in crime prevention, intelligence sharing, and prioritizing policing areas at the level of police beats. Designated, well-trained male and female beat officers directly interact with every family and citizen in their beat to develop familiarity with local happenings. The project emphasizes community participation in law enforcement, making the process more effective. Community policing, as envisioned under this project, is a method distinct from traditional policing—it focuses on cooperation with the community, understanding its needs, prioritizing its security, and utilizing available local resources to address specific issues. Launched in March 2008 in 20 selected police stations, the project is now implemented across all 481 police stations in Kerala. It was rolled out in phases, covering over half the police stations by 2012 and the remainder by 2018. The project has had a significant impact on Kerala society. Related initiatives such as Coastal Vigilance Committees and Road Safety Programmes are also based on the principles of community policing. Appropriate training is provided to frontline police officials to cultivate the right attitude, knowledge, and skills necessary for community policing. Last updated on Wednesday, 6th January 2021.

Title: Reputation of Travancore Police
Content: Sir T Madhava Rao praised the Travancore Police System in his 1867 report, noting high levels of personal and property security where women traveled safely at night. The Travancore State Manual (1940) highlighted that only literate individuals were recruited, with educated personnel often selected for lower ranks. Prominent figures like Mahatma Gandhi commended their discipline and courtesy, comparing them favorably with the London Police.

Title: Achievements and Outcomes of SPMS Implementation
Content: The Sabarimala Pilgrim Management System (SPMS) achieved significant outcomes in managing crowds and improving pilgrim experience. Approximately 25% of pilgrims used the Virtual Queue system, leading to reduced wait times on traditional routes. A database of 14,95,718 pilgrims was created, enabling analytics for future improvements and potential identification of security risks using AI technologies. The system eliminated uncertainty around darshan timing and streamlined access to the shrine. During the 2019–2020 season, 8,32,391 pilgrims arrived out of 14,95,718 total bookings, representing a visit rate of 55.66%. Factors affecting turnout included strict adherence to scheduled time slots and temporary reliance on manual verification due to connectivity issues. Overall, SPMS enhanced service delivery, provided alternate statistical insights, and aided investigations in case of incidents.

Title: Kerala State Right to Service Act, 2012 Overview
Content: The Kerala State Right to Service Act, 2012 came into force on 1 November 2012. The Act ensures effective and time-bound redress of citizen grievances, delivery of services to the public, and holds government servants accountable in cases of default. It establishes a two-tier appellate system for addressing grievances. Under Section 5 of the Act, designated officers must either provide a requested service or reject the application within a stipulated time. Failure to comply results in a penalty ranging from Rs. 500 to Rs. 5,000. Section 3 mandates that every government department, head of department, local self-government institution, and statutory body notify the services they offer, the designated officers responsible, and the time limits for service delivery within six months of the Act's commencement. The Act outlines procedures for filing appeals and specifies how first and second appellate authorities handle them. These authorities possess powers similar to civil courts regarding document inspection, summoning individuals, and other prescribed matters.

Title: Cyber Dome
Content: To address growing cyber threats and the need for advanced cybersecurity measures, Kerala Police has set up a Hi-Tech Center called 'Cyber Dome' for cyber security and innovation. The center performs activities like internet monitoring, virtual policing, social media monitoring, automated threat intelligence, cyber forensics, tracking systems for child protection, criminal apprehension software, safe surfing web applications, child ID application, image analysis software, online network investigation tools, access blocking applications, stolen vehicle database management, and cyber security awareness programs. It also includes a research division focusing on mobile technology-based cyber forensics, new approaches to cybercrime, improving police efficiency through IT infrastructure, and neural analysis. The project was approved by the Government of Kerala via G.O (Ms.) No.167/2014/Home dated 22/08/2014, with contributions from the IT industry on a pro-bono basis.

Title: cOcOn
Content: cOcOn, previously known as Cyber Safe, is an annual event conducted as part of the International Information Security Day. The c0c0n annual conferences began in 2008 as an initiative of Kerala Police in collaboration with the Information Security Research Organization (ISRA). The themes of c0c0n change every year. Previous themes have included tackling cyber terror, ethical hacking, free tools for cyber investigation, artificial intelligence, security compliance, passwordless economy, embedded systems, securing payment data, routing protocols for enhanced anonymity, tackling fake news, threat hunting, statistical correlations in tracking adversaries, third-party risk management, cloud security, and blockchain technology. c0c0n 2019 was held on 27th and 28th September 2019.

Title: Vehicle Theft Prevention Tips
Content: To protect your vehicle from theft, observe the following precautions: Always lock your vehicle and keep windows fully closed, ensuring quarter glasses are secure. Never leave the key in the ignition. Double-check that all doors, including the boot, are properly locked. Do not leave valuables inside the car, even if locked. Install a car alarm system. Avoid keeping important documents in the glove box or boot. Refrain from offering rides to strangers.

Title: Internet Safety Tips for Citizens
Content: When using the internet, avoid overconfidence in your own safety practices. Even if you're cautious, consider whether you truly know the people you interact with online. Inform trusted individuals if you plan to meet someone you've met online. Be mindful that any cordial relationship online might sour, leading to misuse of previously shared photos, chats, or videos. Protect sensitive data by not disclosing passwords and securing devices with strong authentication methods. Stay vigilant about updating security tools and avoid complacency in maintaining digital hygiene.

Title: FINGER PRINT BUREAU - Overview and History
Content: The FINGER PRINT BUREAU is an important scientific investigation wing of the Kerala Police that assists various investigative agencies in fighting criminal activities. Its services are also utilized by central police organizations such as the CBI and NIA, as well as other state police forces. The bureau maintains conviction details and fingerprints of all individuals convicted in the state of Kerala. The history of the bureau dates back to the Travancore Finger Print Bureau, established on 02-05-1900 by Maharaja Sree Moolam Thirunal. The Cochin state fingerprint records, started in September 1905, were later merged with Travancore's to form the Travancore-Cochin Bureau on 30-06-1950. Upon the formation of Kerala state in 1956, the Malabar district’s fingerprint records were integrated to establish the Kerala State Finger Print Bureau. Notably, the world’s first fingerprint bureau was established in Calcutta in 1897.

Title: CAP Desk - Peer Support Initiative Under Project Chiri
Content: The CAP (Children & Police) Desk is a peer-to-peer support program designed to assist children in distress via friendly telephone interactions. It builds upon the successful 'Kutty Desk' model initiated during the early stages of the lockdown, which supported 4700 children. The program involves training 15 smart children from each police district, including senior Student Police Cadets and participants of the Our Responsibility to Children (ORC) program. These volunteers provide companionship and emotional support to distressed peers, encourage engagement in productive activities, and conduct follow-up calls. Mentors, psychologists, and mental health experts support the volunteers. Mentors include teachers and resource persons from SPC and ORC programs. Psychologists from ORC and government projects perform initial assessments and refer cases needing expert attention to a panel of psychiatrists and specialists.

Title: Formation of Modern Kerala Police
Content: Following India's linguistic reorganization, Kerala State was formed on November 1, 1956, merging Travancore, Cochin, and Malabar regions. This led to significant restructuring of the entire police establishment. Excluding MSP and Fire Force, Kerala Police strength stood at 11,312 in 1956. Special powers were granted via the Kerala Police Act of 1960. India's first Women's Police Station opened in Kozhikode in 1973, inaugurated by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. In 1981, the head of the department's designation changed to Director General of Police (DGP), with T. Anantha Sankara Iyer becoming Kerala's first DGP.

Title: Cyber Security Guidelines for Safe Internet Usage
Content: To protect yourself in the digital world, follow these cybersecurity guidelines. Be cautious about sharing private information online, as relationships may turn hostile and your data could be misused. Never share passwords with anyone, even trusted friends. Always disconnect or cover your webcam when not in use, as spyware can activate it without your knowledge. Avoid allowing others to download pirated content using your devices, and ensure your computers and mobile phones are secured with passwords. Use credible and updated antivirus or security software regularly. Prefer visiting lawful websites and look for 'https' protocol for better security. Do not open emails from unknown sources, and respect the privacy and security of others just as you would want yours respected. Refrain from trusting online friendships blindly, and never share personal, family, or banking details with strangers. Report inappropriate messages to parents, friends, or authorities. Decline meeting requests from online acquaintances. Avoid using copyrighted material without permission and do not click on suspicious links. Free software or mobile applications may carry viruses or malicious code.

Title: Repeater Stations and Communication Infrastructure
Content: 70 Local Repeater Stations are functioning for the purpose of traffic and law & order management. Considering the demand of voice communication channels and other constrains in VHF (low and high band frequencies), Department also obtained license for UHF (Ultra High Frequency) operations in some major towns of the Kerala and the same is functioning. Through effective patching of various frequencies, seamless communication is possible between a small set in one district and another in a remote district.

Title: Pain and Palliative Care Unit in KAP IV Battalion
Content: A Pain and Palliative unit is functioning in this unit under Janamythri Kendram KAP4 since 2008. This is registered under Charitable Societies Act as per Reg. No. S884/2008. The objects of the unit are to give palliative care to those who are bedridden due to prolonged illness/accidents/old age/orphans. Home care is provided to the patients twice a week. Rehabilitation training for paraplegia patients is also provided. The main resources of this unit are voluntary contributions of police personnel of this unit, medical equipment provided by Janamythri Suraksha schemes, and equipment provided by local Self Government. Approximately about 1000 patients in Kalliassery, Aanthoor, Pappinassery Panchayaths, and Thaliparamba Municipality were provided treatment by this unit since 2008 onwards. Apart from the above, everyday free meals are provided to the students of Blind School Dharmasala. These students come from very poor backgrounds. This is also undertaken through the voluntary contribution of police personnel of this unit.

Title: Kerala Police Organizational Structure
Content: The Kerala Police is organized under the State Police Headquarters. The Additional Director General of Police (ADGP) oversees the Law & Order wing. The state is divided into two police zones: North Zone and South Zone, each headed by an Inspector General of Police. These zones are further subdivided into four Police Ranges: Thiruvananthapuram Range, Ernakulam Range, Thrissur Range, and Kannur Range, each led by a Deputy Inspector General of Police. Each range comprises between three to five police districts, commanded by District Police Chiefs typically holding the rank of Superintendent of Police.

Title: Highway Police
Content: This system was introduced in the Kerala Police vide PHQ Circular No.9/02, dated 09/08/02 and order No. U6-51825/02, dated 08/05/03 respectively with objectives controlling Traffic, enforcement of Traffic Laws, prevention of Road Accidents, providing immediate attention and assistance to victims of accidents, handling of Law & Order issues, and enforcement of Laws on Highways, etc. Each Highway Police Vehicle is assigned an 'Operational area' and a Base Station. The Officers and men are deployed for duty in the Highway Police from various Police Stations in the District. The duties and responsibilities of the Highway Police Personnel are: Traffic Enforcement with a view to avoid road accidents and bring immediate relief to victims of accident. Traffic control at the places where there are chances of traffic jams at and places where people gather in large numbers such as Schools, Places of Worship, Hospitals etc. Attend to all L&O issues on the Highways. Attend any distress call from any person on Highway. Check for any illicit transportation of contraband articles, smuggling of goods, stolen vehicles etc. Attend to all information regarding crimes of trivial in nature on the Highways in time. To render assistance to the traveling public on the Highways, as and when needed with care and courtesy. Act as a moving Police Station to help public etc. At present a total of 44 Highway Police Patrols are functioning along all the important Roads in Kerala. New Innova Vehicles are used for the purpose.

Title: Highway Police
Content: Each Vehicle carries various Records, Arms, and other traffic-related equipments (including stretchers, First-Aids, Boxes, Traffic Enforcement items, etc.). Each Vehicle has been provided with a Wireless Set and a Mobile Phone for easy communication. In addition to this, a Highway Alert Number 9846 100 100 has been widely publicized, and any person can contact this number to get the assistance of the Highway Police round the clock. In the last many years, the Highway Police helped in averting many major accidents, provided timely medical help to a large number of accident victims in odd hours, detected many Crime cases and arrested criminals. The success story continues.

Title: Objectives of the Student Police Cadet (SPC) Project
Content: The objectives of the Student Police Cadet (SPC) Project include: To mould a generation of youth who willingly respect and abide by law, and who practice civic sense, democratic behavior and selfless service to society as the natural way of life. To facilitate development of good health, physical and mental fitness, self-control and discipline in youth, thereby enhancing their capacity for hard work and personal achievement. To enable youth to work with police and other enforcement authorities including Forest, Transport, and Excise in preventing crime, maintaining law and order, promoting road safety, and improving internal security and disaster management. To develop social commitment in youth and empower them against deviant behavior in themselves and others, thereby preventing growth of social evils such as drug and alcohol abuse, intolerance, vandalism, separatism, and terrorism in society. To enable youth to explore and develop their inner potential in achieving success, by inculcating in them leadership, teamwork skills, innovative thinking and problem-solving ability. To increase knowledge and understanding of effective use of Information and Communications Technology (ICT) among youth, preventing its negative influence and enabling them to benefit from the vast potential of ICT. To motivate youth to develop secular outlook, respect for others' fundamental rights and willingness to carry out their fundamental duties as enshrined in the Constitution of India by developing in them qualities of Patriotism, Open-mindedness, Large-heartedness, Inclusiveness, Capability and Effectiveness (POLICE).

Title: Child Friendly Police Stations (CFPS) - Overview
Content: Child Friendly Police Stations (CFPS) are police stations in Kerala that demonstrate child friendliness in attitude, ambience, infrastructure, procedure, and enforcement. They facilitate partnership, function as Knowledge Hubs, and act as strict enforcers of child-related laws. After a successful pilot, 110 police stations have been transformed into CFPS following capacity-building workshops organized in collaboration with UNICEF. The initiative aims to ensure that children grow up in an atmosphere of affection, protection, and care; any abuse or atrocity against a child is promptly and thoroughly investigated; children at risk are identified early and supported; parents, teachers, and society are aware of children's rights; children know their rights and responsibilities; children travel safely; no child is engaged in labor or begging; and police stations become trusted places for addressing child-related issues.

Title: Traffic Police
Content:
Traffic Police
Over the years, the traffic police of the state has tried several innovative programmes to contain road traffic accidents. Identification of Accident Spots (Black Spots) in all the districts was conducted as a joint exercise by police and citizens. The data collected was analyzed in order to identify the causes and contributory factors.
Enforcement was focused on these black spots to reduce accidents. Body worn cameras were pressed into services in Thiruvanthapuram and Kochi to minimize conflict during traffic checks.
In order to attract children who would have the greatest multiplier effect in terms of promotion of traffic awareness, a traffic mascot: Pappu Zebra was designed. Programmes are conducted regularly in schools. Further, six mobile traffic training parks with interactive terminals and projectors have been commissioned to teach children about traffic rules. These units move from place to place. A Traffic Training School has been set up in Kerala Police Academy to train personnel.

Title: Virtual Adalath for Redressal of Grievances of Police Personnel
Content: The Virtual Adalath initiative is designed to address the official and personal grievances of police personnel in Kerala. Spouses of police personnel may also interact with the State Police Chiefs or submit complaints via email or post. A dedicated cell operates at Police Headquarters (PHQ) to manage these complaints. All grievances can be submitted via email to spctalks.pol@keral.gov.in or sent by post. The Virtual Adalath sessions are held every Thursday at 10:30 AM, covering two districts per session. A meeting link is provided to each petitioner in advance. Complaints must be received at least five days prior to the scheduled Adalath and should be sent to the 'TALK WITH THE COPS' Cell at PHQ. During each session, the respective District Police Commissioners (DPCs), Additional Superintendents of Police (Addl. SP), Managers, and officers from the A, F, and G Branches (JS level) are required to attend. Separate WhatsApp groups have been created at the district level by District Police Chiefs, and another group is maintained jointly by District Police Chiefs, Addl. SPs, and PHQ officials for coordination purposes. Last updated on Saturday, 5th February 2022.

Title: Rapid Response and Rescue Force (RRRF) - Organizational Structure
Content: RRRF is deployed across four Wings in four Police Ranges: TVPM Wing at SAP, EKM Wing at ARC, Trippunithura, TSR Wing at ARC, Thrissur, and KNR Wing at KAP 4 Bn, KNR. The force is internally divided into three specialized wings: Quick Response Team (QRT), Disaster Response Team (DRT), and VIP Security Wing. While QRT and DRT Wings are distributed among the four police ranges, the VIP Security Wing operates under the RRRF TVPM Wing. Personnel from the DRT Wing receive Disaster Management training and are integrated into the State Disaster Response Force.

Title: Organisational Structure of Kerala State Finger Print Bureau
Content: The Kerala State Finger Print Bureau, under the Police Department, is headed by a Director and operates directly under the Additional Director General of Police, State Crime Records Bureau. The Bureau consists of the State Finger Print Bureau located in Thiruvananthapuram and nineteen district/city-level fingerprint bureaus, referred to as Single Digit Finger Print Bureaux.

Title: Road Safety Advice for Speeders
Content: Driving at high speeds reduces reaction time and increases stopping distances significantly. For example, a vehicle traveling at 80 km/h requires 76 meters to stop, while at 100 km/h, it needs 112 meters. Drivers should regularly assess their speed by asking: Can I stop in time if the vehicle ahead brakes suddenly? Is my speed appropriate for the road and traffic conditions? Am I in the correct gear? Additionally, evaluate the road and environmental factors such as whether the road is wet, greasy, or uneven; if there are roadside encroachments or parked vehicles; and if rain is likely.

Title: Grassroot Awareness Initiatives Under Project Chiri

Title: Student Police Cadet (SPC) Project Overview
Content: The Student Police Cadet (SPC) Project is a school-based initiative by Kerala Police, implemented jointly by the Departments of Home and Education, and supported by Departments of Transport, Forest, Excise and Local Self-Government. The project trains high school students to evolve as future leaders of a democratic society by inculcating in them respect for the law, discipline, civic sense, empathy for vulnerable sections of society and resistance to social evils. The project also enables youth to explore and develop their innate capabilities, thereby empowering them to resist the growth of negative tendencies such as social intolerance, substance abuse, deviant behavior, and anti-establishment violence. Equally, it strengthens within them commitment towards their family, the community, and the environment. The Project was launched on August 2, 2010 in 127 high schools/higher secondary schools across Kerala, with 11,176 students, both boys and girls, enrolled as Cadets and 254 teachers trained as school-level Community Police Officers (CPOs). The project was gradually expanded and by April 2020, it was implemented in 702 schools located in 19 police districts of Kerala with a combined strength of 60,000 cadets and 1,404 CPOs. On July 21, 2018, the Union Home Minister announced that the SPC project developed by Kerala Police had been selected for implementation in all States and Union Territories of India, during the inauguration of the SPC project in Haryana.

Title: Road Safety Tips during Monsoon - General Driving Guidelines
Content: While driving during monsoon, follow these general instructions to ensure safety. Look ahead to anticipate hazards and plan your actions in advance. Pay attention to road signs and markings, and scan the environment to prepare for unexpected events. Stay alert and expect the unexpected by predicting the behavior of other road users. Maintain full control of your vehicle, especially on difficult roads and in mixed traffic conditions. Always drive responsibly, remembering that speed thrills but kills, and you are accountable for others' lives. Follow traffic rules strictly, help others in need, and avoid reckless driving. Do not overtake at junctions, and avoid impatience on the road. Refrain from footpath parking, always keep left while driving, and avoid overtaking from the left side. Pedestrians have the right of way at zebra crossings. Ensure your vehicle passes Pollution Under Control (PUC) checks to reduce pollution. Practice lane driving for safer travel and use horns sparingly. Cooperate with traffic wardens as they are partners in ensuring road safety. Always carry your original driving license and keep a photocopy of your vehicle records. Drivers aged 16 to 18 years should only operate vehicles below 50 cc and without gears. Never drive under the influence of alcohol. Wear protective gear like helmets and seat belts at all times. Avoid listening to loud music and refrain from using mobile phones while driving.

Title: Emergency Response Support System (ERSS) - Kerala Police
Content: The Emergency Response Support System (ERSS) is an emergency response system designed to assist citizens in distress. Citizens can seek police support by calling 112. Introduced by the Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India, under the National Emergency Response System (NERS), ERSS establishes a single emergency number '112' across the country, integrating existing emergency numbers such as 100 (Police), 101 (Fire & Rescue Service), and 108 (Ambulance Services). In Kerala, the Police Department is currently the only agency integrated with this system. The project was implemented with administrative sanction from the Government of Kerala via GO(Rt) No.2673/Home dated 12/10/17, and M/s C-DAC, Thiruvananthapuram was designated as the implementing agency through GO(Rt) No. 3113/2017/Home dated 23/11/17. The State-wide Control Room, known as the State Emergency Response Centre, functions at Police Headquarters, Thiruvananthapuram. District Coordination Centres (DCCs) have also been established in specified locations, particularly within Control Rooms. These centres operate with three layers of workforce: Case Record Management (CRM), Computer Aided Dispatchers (CAD), and Command Centre Supervisors (CCS), each assigned specific responsibilities. The digital infrastructure ensures rapid processing of distress signals received via voice calls, SMS, emails, panic-SOS requests, or web requests. Messages are dispatched from the State Control Room to the nearest police vehicle through DCCs, and all activities during the response process are monitored centrally. Future plans include integrating services like Fire & Rescue, Ambulance, and Disaster Management for broader utility. For inquiries, contact erssphq.pol@kerala.gov.in. Last updated on Monday, 3rd April 2023.

Title: Personal Safety Tips – Preventing Bag Snatching While Travelling
Content: To avoid bag snatching while traveling, adhere to the following safety measures: Carry your purse close to your body and slightly in front. Keep your purse closed and fastened at all times; do not leave it unattended on counters. Only carry necessary amounts of money. If someone tries to snatch your bag, let it go to avoid risking personal injury.

Title: Kerala Police District Administration Hierarchy
Content: All District Police officers are supported by Additional Superintendents of Police. These Sub Divisions are further divided into Police Station areas. Each Police Station is commanded by an Inspector of Police, who is assisted by Sub Inspectors, Additional Sub Inspectors, Senior Civil Police Officers, and Civil Police Officers. Title: Nirbhaya Project Overview
Content: The Nirbhaya Kerala - Surakshitha Kerala programme was launched by the Kerala Home Department on 1st August 2014 on a pilot basis in the city to prevent abuse against women and children. As part of the implementation, 120 women volunteers were recruited from 74 divisions in the Kochi Corporation. The project focuses on a three-point agenda: Prevention, Prosecution, and Protection. In the area of Prevention, interventions include sensitizing society, empowering vulnerable groups, and addressing contributing factors like alcoholism, gender discrimination, and consumerism. For Prosecution, the policy emphasizes formulating strong laws to ensure rigorous punishment for offenders, acting as a deterrent. It specifically targets child abuse, commercial sexual exploitation, and sex trafficking, representing the worst forms of sexual violence in the state. The scheme is implemented jointly by the departments of Social Welfare, SC/ST, Police, Health, Labour, and Local Self Government in coordination with NGOs.

Title: Project HOPE - Kerala Police
Content: Project HOPE is an initiative by the Kerala Police aimed at supporting students who have failed the SSLC (Class X) and Plus Two (Class XII) examinations or have dropped out of school. The project was initiated to address the social isolation and low self-esteem experienced by these students, which can lead them away from mainstream society and into lifestyles harmful to themselves and others. Based on studies of juveniles in police custody, it was found that many had drifted away from education after failing key exams. Project HOPE provides classes to help these students pass their exams and reintegrate into society. Since the 2019-20 academic year, the project has been implemented across all districts in Kerala. Results show that out of 522 SSLC candidates supported by the project, 465 passed, and out of 199 Plus Two candidates, 76 passed.

Title: Unique Features of Child Friendly Police Stations (CFPS)
Content: Each Child Friendly Police Station includes several unique features designed to support children: a separate, comfortable space for interacting with children; seating, toilets, and safe drinking water facilities for children; a welcoming ambience featuring attractive artwork and recreational options; designated areas for women, especially nursing mothers; visible information boards displaying the names and contact details of Child Welfare Officers; educational and communication materials on child rights; a mini library stocked with books, newspapers, magazines, and legal resources related to children; readiness to treat each visiting child with personal care and respect; prioritization of the best interests of the child in all matters; respectful treatment regardless of age, gender, religion, or caste; zero tolerance for violence, abuse, or exploitation of children; empathetic responses to traumatized children; comprehensive knowledge of laws concerning children; training in psychological first aid for mental distress, depression, suicidal tendencies, substance abuse, and behavioral issues; non-judgmental listening skills and access to expert help when needed; recognition that reporting to a police station is often a last resort for victims; emphasis on understanding 'why' rather than merely recording 'what' from children in conflict with the law; acknowledgment that juvenile delinquency results from broader systemic failures; adoption of mentoring roles by officers dealing with children; and adherence to guidelines outlined in Annexure I – Tips for Communicating with Children.

Title: Sabarimala Pilgrim Management System (SPMS)
Content: The Sabarimala Pilgrim Management System (SPMS) is a digital platform launched in 2019 to manage the increasing number of pilgrims visiting the Sabarimala temple during the pilgrimage season from November to January. It integrates services from the Kerala Police, Travancore Devaswom Board, and KSRTC, allowing devotees to access virtual queue services, book religious offerings, and reserve long-distance bus tickets through a single portal at https://sabarimalaonline.org. The system enables devotees to register by providing personal details including name, age, address, contact number, photograph, and identity card information. Upon successful booking, an SMS is sent, and barcoded e-tickets specifying the date and time slot for darshan must be printed and carried along with photo ID during the pilgrimage. Group booking options are also available. The service is free of charge. Verification counters at Pampa issue entry cards upon presentation of e-tickets and IDs. Facilitation centers were set up at Erumeli, Kumuli, Pathanamthitta bus stand, and Vadasserikkara for those unable to book online; 51,415 pilgrims used these centers during the 2019–2020 season.

Title: Persons Whose Photographs Must Be Taken for Record Purposes
Content: Photographs must be taken of individuals convicted under Chapters XII or XVII of the Indian Penal Code for offenses punishable with rigorous imprisonment for one year or more, or those liable to enhanced punishment upon repeat offenses. Also included are persons ordered by a First-Class Magistrate to have their photographs taken during investigations or proceedings under the Code of Criminal Procedure, provided they were previously arrested in connection with the matter. Under-trial prisoners are exempt from being photographed. In cases of resistance or refusal to be photographed under these provisions, police officers may lawfully employ necessary means to secure compliance, as per Section 6(1) of the Identification of Prisoners Act, 1920 and Section 7 of the Kerala Identification of Prisoners Act, 1963. Such refusal constitutes an offense under Section 186 of the Indian Penal Code, according to Section 6(2) of the 1920 Act and Section 7 of the 1963 State Act. Photographs of persons released without trial, discharged, or acquitted are also recorded. Guidelines from the National Human Rights Commission require full video and photographic coverage of post-mortem examinations in cases of death due to police action, aiming to document injuries suggesting custodial torture, support findings through visual evidence, and enable future reviews if needed. During video recording, the conducting doctor's narration of initial observations must be captured audibly.

Title: Tips for Safe Online Chatting for Children
Content: Position the computer in your main living space and ensure the monitor faces outward into the room to prevent secrecy. Work as a team to set boundaries by discussing with your child what websites, chat rooms, and topics are appropriate. Set logical consequences for rule violations, such as being grounded from the internet for one week, but do not threaten permanent bans. Stress that children must report any weird or upsetting messages without fear of punishment or internet restriction. Make it clear that they are not to blame for others' inappropriate behavior. Set strict time limits for internet chat use and enforce them to prevent internet addiction. Teach children that people in chat rooms are always strangers regardless of familiarity and should not be fully trusted. Instruct them never to share personal information such as real names, schools, phone numbers, or addresses online. Do not allow children to remain unsupervised online for extended periods. Ensure chat time occurs when parents are present to check in regularly. Emphasize polite and respectful behavior during all online interactions. Reassure children that no one can harm them through the internet as long as they follow established rules. Take an active interest in your child’s online activities. Avoid using the internet as a babysitter. Learn to surf the web and chat online yourself, or ask your child to teach you.

Title: Kerala Armed Police - I (KAP I) Battalion Overview
Content: Kerala Armed Police - I (KAP I) Battalion is situated at Tripunithura, in Ernakulam District, which is 4 km away from the North East of Tripunithura Municipality. The battalion was formed on 17th November 1972 as per Government Order (Ms) 175/72 Home dated 17th November 1972 and was initially designated as KAP for Central Range with Headquarters at Thrissur under the control of Deputy Inspector General, Central Range. The headquarters of the battalion was shifted from Thrissur to Tripunithura in Ernakulam district on 01.07.2019. KAP I is one of the outstanding battalions and plays a key role in maintaining law and order, crowd control, general election duties inside and outside the state, and duties in communally disturbed areas. Its main objective is to assist local police in maintaining law and order in society. The feeder district for this battalion is Ernakulam. The Commandant is the Chief of the Battalion and is assisted by the Deputy Commandant and Assistant Commandants in administrative matters. Deployment orders in various districts are issued by the ADGP or DIG of Police, Armed Police Battalions Kerala.

Title: India Reserve Battalion - Kerala Police
Content: The Government of India sanctioned the raising of the India Reserve Battalion (IRBn) in Kerala, covering 75% of the standard cost for its establishment. This decision was communicated through Govt letter D.O No.1-11034/2/2008-IS-IV dated 06th October 2008 and GO(MS) No.203/08/HOME dated 01.12.2008. The battalion has a total strength of 1007 personnel, inclusive of police personnel, ministerial staff, and camp followers. The Central Government holds the primary authority to deploy the IRBn anywhere in the country as required, and the State Government is obligated to comply with such deployment requests. The IRBn is divided into two wings: the Regular Wing with 475 posts and the Commando Wing with 200 posts out of the total 675 police constable positions. Additionally, based on GO(MS)196/2015/HOME/Thiruvananthapuram dated 09/09/2015, 50 commando posts were created for enhanced security at Sree Padmanabha Swamy Temple, and 210 additional commando posts were sanctioned for various battalions within IRBn. Selection of personnel for the Regular Wing and Commando Wing follows different procedures, conducted by the Kerala Public Service Commission. The primary mission of the IRBn includes preventing insurgency, extremism, and other antisocial activities against the nation. It is also deployed during national emergencies such as calamities and disasters.

Title: Kerala Police Telecommunication Overview

Police Telecommunication is functioning as per the Rules and Procedures of Government of India viz. Wireless and Telegraphic Act 1932, Radio Procedures and relevant Manuals. The basic duties and responsibilities of this Unit are to provide Telecommunication network to aid the day to day Policing in the districts, to maintain the equipment and to repair the same through regular monitoring. They also have an independent Training wing and Maintenance and Repair Workshop. Other important duties include installation of special communication systems for VVIP Security bandobust, Sabarimala pilgrimage season, Election duties, disaster management and grave Law and order situations etc.

Title: Special Armed Police (SAP) Battalion - Overview and History
Content: The Special Armed Police (SAP) Battalion was established on 5th August 1958 from the erstwhile General Armed Reserve of Travancore-Cochin State, as per GO No. H2/19354/1953 CS dated 04.09.1955. It is stationed in the old Leprosy Hospital Campus of Peroorkada, Thiruvananthapuram. A Gratitude Stone in memory of Dr. Fernandez of the old Leprosy Hospital is preserved in the SAP Campus. This is the second Armed Police Battalion of the State. The second Battalion of the SAP was formed on 01.09.1963 and was deployed to Nagaland to combat insurgency. The Battalion served in Nagaland for over three years and received public and governmental appreciation for its efforts. A memento from Nagaland authorities is kept at the Battalion Headquarters. Sri. Kailasa Nathan was the first Commandant of the SAP Battalion. The SAP camp occupies 30.6 acres of land, and the SAP Family Quarters cover 17.78 acres, located under survey numbers 1302, 1303, 1304, 1305, 1283, and 1284 of Peroorkada Village in Thiruvananthapuram Taluk. SAP also operates a Sub Camp at Milk Colony, Poonthura, covering 4 acres of land under survey number 2615 in Muttathara Village.

Title: Internet Banking Safety Tips
Content: To ensure safe internet banking, never respond to any email requesting confirmation, upgrading, renewal, or validation of account or card details, even if it seems to come from your bank. Always look for the padlock icon in the browser during secure transactions. Do not share your login password or OTP (online transaction password) with anyone, including friends, family, or bank employees. Avoid conducting financial transactions from cybercafes or shared computers. Disable the 'Auto Complete' function on browsers to prevent automatic filling of login credentials. Clear browser cache and history after each session when using shared devices. Use a browser that supports encryption. Review account statements regularly and report discrepancies promptly. Set a passcode on mobile devices to protect one-time verification codes. Report lost or stolen cards immediately to limit unauthorized usage and liability.

Title: GIVERS - Support for Family Members of Police Martyrs
Content: GIVERS is a new initiative by the Kerala Police aimed at helping and supporting the family members of Police Martyrs. This includes martyrs from the Kerala Police or any other Police Force in the country, provided they reside in Kerala. Retired police officers are encouraged to actively participate in ensuring the welfare of these families. The Kerala State Police Pensioners Welfare Association is also involved in this initiative, contributing to the planning and implementation of programs designed to support the surviving members of Police Martyrs' families living in the state. Title: Hi-Tech Crime Enquiry Cell - Kerala Police
Content: The Hi-Tech Crime Enquiry Cell is a specialized unit under the Kerala Police, established on 05th May 2006 by a special order of the Director General of Police (DGP) of Kerala. It operates under the direct supervision of the Superintendent of Police (SP) Crimes and the overall command of the Additional Director General of Police, Crimes. The cell was created to prevent and detect serious and organized cyber crimes, collaborating with government agencies, the private sector, academic institutions, and foreign counterparts. Its primary role includes conducting preliminary inquiries into offenses such as hacking of websites, online cheating, email hacking, Nigerian scams, phishing, source code theft, identity theft, child pornography, social media abuse, mobile phone abuse, and loss or theft of mobile phones. These also include an expanding range of computer, internet, and mobile phone-facilitated crimes. The Hi-Tech Crime Enquiry Cell serves as an expert support and analysis unit for various police stations and units investigating cyber crimes or other technology-assisted crimes requiring technical expertise for evidence retrieval. However, it does not have the authority to register criminal cases or independently investigate them. Officers from the cell actively engage in awareness programs about cyber crimes and their prevention among students, organizational employees, and the general public. Additionally, this cell acts as the nodal unit for interactions between Kerala Police and entities such as CDAC, C-DIT, NIC, Kerala IT Mission, KELTRON, Reprographic Centre, BSNL, and all Internet Service Providers regarding crime investigation and related matters.

Title: Malabar Special Police - History and Overview
Content: The Malabar Special Police (MSP) has its origins in the Nayar Sibbandy Corps, raised under native chieftains towards the end of the 18th century to counteract the Moplahs. It evolved through various stages, including a force of 500 armed policemen primarily tasked with revenue collection. The MSP was made permanent in 1897. During periods of rebellion, the force proved effective against guerrilla tactics despite being initially armed with Martin Henri single-shot rifles. On 30th September 1921, the Government sanctioned a structure comprising 6 British Officers, 8 Subedars, 16 Jamadars, 60 Havildars, and 600 Constables organized into Auxiliary Police companies, which later became known as the Malabar Special Police. The unit was commanded by an Indian Civil Service officer, a probationary Assistant Superintendent of Police, and ex-British Army officers, with recruits trained in Cannanore. The MSP gained recognition for excellence in discipline, marching, and combat performance even under harsh conditions. Noted for expertise in guerrilla warfare, the force's reputation extended beyond the state. In 1932, the MSP was reorganized into 4 companies, expanded to 16 during World War II, then reduced to 12 after a strike in 1946. Upon the formation of Kerala State, six companies were transferred to Madras State while six remained in Kerala. An additional three companies were added in 1957 during the Vimochana Samaram. Currently, the MSP consists of seven companies headquartered in Malappuram. Facilities include motor vehicle workshops where new drivers receive training, a central library, a computer center, and a school.

Title: Purpose and Priorities of CCSE Initiative
Content: Child pornography involves exploiting children for sexual stimulation and includes any form of media depicting sexual acts involving minors, whether real or simulated. This includes content shared via social media platforms like Telegram, Facebook, WhatsApp, written materials, photos, animations, films, and video games. With the rise of internet usage and digital technologies, child pornography has become increasingly accessible through various online channels. The CCSE initiative aims to combat this growing threat by focusing on prevention, detection, and prosecution of perpetrators involved in producing, distributing, or accessing such material. A major priority is identifying and dismantling networks that operate anonymously using tools such as darknets, VPNs, and encrypted messaging services.

Title: Finger Print Attestation Service by Kerala Police
Content: The Finger Print Bureau of Kerala Police provides fingerprint attestation services required for immigration purposes by various countries. Applicants must approach Tester Inspectors of the District Finger Print Bureau. The service is available with a prior appointment during the first three weeks of each month. A fee of Rs. 1500/- is required for the attestation, and Rs. 150/- for each additional copy. This amount should be remitted in any Government treasury under the account head '0055-00-103-99'. Title: Development of Modern Policing in Travancore
Content:
Under British rule, a semblance of a modern police force developed in late 19th century Travancore. Oliver H. Bensley became the first Superintendent of Police in 1881, followed by William H. Pitt as Police Commissioner in 1921. Major reorganization occurred in 1939 when the post of Inspector General of Police was introduced. Mr. Khan Bahadur Sayid Abdul Karim Sahib Suhrawady was the first IGP. The police structure included:
- Inspector General of Police: 1
- Deputy Inspector General of Police: 1
- District Superintendents of Police: 3
- Assistant Superintendents of Police: 6
- Inspectors: 81
- Head Constables: 236
- Police Constables: 2337
Significant reforms affected the General Executive Wing, Criminal Intelligence Wing, Reserve Force, Special Police, and Traffic Wing. By 1947, total police strength reached 3626. N. Chandrasekharan Nair served as IGP from August 21, 1948, continuing post-merger with Cochin in 1952 and after Kerala state formation in 1956.

Title: Aparajitha is Online - Online Harassment Grievance Redressal Mechanism
Content: "Aparajitha is Online" is a quick response mechanism for the grievance redressal of online-based harassment of women and girls. Most such cases of online harassment go unreported due to societal pressures, fear of backlash, or because the offender may be a close acquaintance or relative using blackmail tactics. Victims often feel insecure or lack confidence in approaching the police. To address these challenges, a sensitive, technically robust, and swift response system has been established. The State-level oversight is handled by the Superintendent of Police (SP), Women Cell, who is also responsible for grievance redressal specifically related to online harassment complaints. At the local level, designated Women Circle Police Officers (WCPOs) and Women Sub-Circle Police Officers (WSCPOs), trained in cyber-related matters, manage complaints. Strict confidentiality regarding the identity of victims and their families is maintained to prevent victim shaming or further harassment. Complaints must be sent via email to aparajitha.pol@kerala.gov.in and will be forwarded to specially designated emails at the police station level, accessible only by authorized WCPOs/WSCPOs. These officers are supported by cyber cells at the police station, district, and state levels—including Hi-Tech Cells and Cyber Dome—for identification and location of offenders. Once identified, legal action can be pursued as necessary, with coordination between the Station House Officer (SHO), District Police Chief, and SP Women Cell. A dedicated helpline number is available for assistance: 9497996992. Last updated on Wednesday, 5th July 2023 PM.

Title: Safety Tips for Using Mobile Banking Applications
Content: Download banking applications only from trusted sources, preferably those marked with a TRUSTED symbol. Ensure the app generates an OTP for every transaction. Use applications recommended by banking authorities as they are more secure. Secure your mobile phone with a passcode to prevent unauthorized access to OTPs. Keep both the mobile device and the banking application updated. Verify that the app does not capture confidential data unnecessarily. Report incorrect or fraudulent transactions immediately to banking authorities and, if necessary, to the police. Incidents can be reported via toll-free numbers provided by banks or through official email channels. Follow up on reports if no action or refund is initiated, and escalate to the nearest police station or cyber crime cell if required.

Title: Safety Tips for Using Debit/Credit Cards
Content: Do not share card details, OTPs, or ATM card passwords with anyone. Avoid downloading third-party applications related to online payments. Use trusted websites and applications for online transactions. Prefer mobile data over public Wi-Fi for payment activities. Opt for credit cards instead of debit cards where possible. Do not conduct online payments on public computers. Create strong passwords containing alphanumeric and special characters, and change them regularly. Memorize your PIN and do not write it down, especially on the card. Change your PIN periodically. Avoid transactions if suspicious devices are attached to card readers. Cover the keypad when entering your PIN. Enable transaction alerts from your bank. Keep customer IDs and PINs confidential. Press the cancel button on card machines before leaving. Do not write your PIN on receipts or bills.

Title: Pol-Blood - Blood Donation and Request Service by Kerala Police
Content: Kerala Police, in association with KSACS, has introduced a citizen service called 'Pol-Blood', available through the official mobile app 'Pol-App'. This service aims to connect blood donors and recipients to ensure timely availability of blood during medical emergencies. Pol-Blood offers two main services: Blood Donor Service and Blood Recipient Service. Individuals can register as donors by providing their blood group, contact number, and preferred location for donation. Donors can also view existing blood requests and respond accordingly. Recipients can submit a blood request by providing details such as blood group, number of units required, hospital name, blood bank details, required date and time, and bystander contact information. The Pol-Blood Control Room manages both donor willingness and recipient requests, facilitating communication between parties and ensuring each request is resolved effectively. This service is designed to be citizen-centric and supportive during emergency situations.

Title: Outcomes and Impact of CCSE Operations
Content: Through coordinated efforts, the CCSE has significantly disrupted the circulation of child sexual abuse material (CSAM) in Kerala. Operation P-HUNT led to the identification of 126 individuals engaged in widespread distribution of child pornography, resulting in a drastic reduction in membership of related online groups—from 2 lakh to just 5,000. Coordinated raids across all 14 districts have led to approximately 210 searches, registration of 38 cases, and arrest of 42 individuals with evidence. Despite challenges such as difficulty in identifying victims and verifying CSAM sources, the CCSE has instilled fear among offenders by demonstrating successful tracking capabilities even on anonymous platforms. Recognition from ICMEC underscores the effectiveness of Kerala Police’s approach. The CCSE continues its vigilant work to uphold the zero-tolerance stance on child pornography and protect vulnerable children from exploitation.

Title: Cyber Security Guidelines and Best Practices
Content: Always use genuine software. Install the latest updates or patches for the operating system, antivirus, and application software. Limit user privileges on the computer. Always access the internet as a standard user and not as an administrator. Check and verify email sender IDs and web links before opening file attachments and clicking on links in emails and webpages. Phishing emails and SMS are used to obtain user credentials such as usernames, passwords, credit card, and PIN numbers; beware of them. Regularly check the last login details of email accounts. Use strong passwords and different passwords for different online services. Regularly take backups of document files to avoid loss in cases of emergencies like malware infections, hard disk crashes, corrupted applications, and other unforeseen incidents.

Title: Rights of Children Emphasized by CFPS under UNCRC
Content: Child Friendly Police Stations operationalize the following core rights of children as defined by the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC): The Right to Survival – Every child has the right to live a healthy life with access to essential services such as healthcare, nutrition, and shelter. The Right to Protection – Given children's vulnerability during physical and mental development, they require special attention and safeguards to protect them physically, mentally, and socially. The Right to Development – This encompasses the entitlement of every child to participate in and benefit from economic, social, cultural, and political growth, enabling full realization of human rights and freedoms. The Right to Participation – This ensures children and youth can influence decisions affecting their lives and drive positive changes within their communities.

Title: History of Kerala Police Telecommunication
Content: Before independence of India, Malabar Special Police (MSP) and Special Armed Police (SAP) in Kerala were using HF Morse Communication System. Since, 1956 MSP and SAP Signal Units were renamed as Radio Wing of Kerala Police with HF wireless equipments working in CW mode, ie. using Morse Code. Kerala Police Telecommunication unit came into existence in 1994, with VHF communication equipments working in RT mode, ie. voice communication. Even today HF communication is working and is maintained as the most reliable and hot standby in the event of any natural calamity which may lead to collapse of all other long distance communication networks. Today RT communication throughout the state in VHF and UHF for all the L&O duties of the Police force of Kerala is facilitated by Tele unit. This is achieved through a series of Repeater Stations situated on hill-tops and mountains in very remote forest areas, manned by Telecom personnel, working round the clock and in tough climatic conditions. All the RT communications are recorded and stored in Voice Loggers, which are tamper proof and can be retrieved any time for verification. In addition there is a dedicated computer network connecting all the major establishments of Kerala Police.

Title: Strategies Adopted by CCSE for Combating Online Child Exploitation
Content: To effectively tackle online child exploitation, the CCSE Centre employs several strategies including training officers in advanced intelligence-gathering techniques in collaboration with national and international agencies like ICMEC, Interpol, and CBI. Specialized surveillance training over the dark web is also provided. An online portal (www.cybercrime.gov.in) managed by the Ministry of Home Affairs allows citizens to report cybercrimes against women and children, with reports being channeled to CCSE for analysis. The center actively patrols social media platforms, VPNs, and the darknet to gather actionable intelligence. Operation P-HUNT was launched as a covert mission targeting individuals and groups circulating child pornography, particularly active on platforms offering anonymity such as Telegram, WhatsApp, Mega, Dropbox, Omegle, and Chatzy. Social engineering tactics are employed to infiltrate and track suspects across Telegram groups, WhatsApp chats, and international databases.

Title: Formation and Functions of India Reserve Battalion
Content: In 1962, during the National Emergency declared in response to Chinese aggression, several state governments, including Kerala, reorganized their armed police units into India Reserve Battalions. The expenses for forming these battalions were covered by the Central Government. The second Battalion of the SAP was converted into an India Reserve Battalion modeled on the Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF). It comprised 971 members, including ministerial staff, hospital staff, and camp followers. Most officers were directly recruited, while others were appointed on deputation or from the SAP. The battalion was deployed to Nagaland in 1966, where it was equipped with wireless instruments and weapons lent by the Army unit of the Government of Nagaland.

Title: Mounted Police

The beginning of Mounted Police Unit in the State can be traced back to 1880, His Highness the Maharaja of Travancore paved the way and known as “The Rajapramukhas Body Guards” till the Independence of the nation from the British rule. Later the unit was named as “Palace Guard” which was situated in the Body Guard Square, Palayam. The Present Mounted Police Unit was established in the year 1961 vide G.O (MS) 508/Home Dated 14/11/1961 and continued at Cantonment Camp (Body Guard Square), Palayam till 1981. Consequent to the construction of the Assembly Complex at Palayam, the unit was shifted to the present premises. There are 28 stables in Mounted Police Unit (including 3 sick horses’ stables). The Sanctioned Strength of Horses is 25 and the present strength is 25. The Reserve Inspector, Mounted Police Unit is the Controlling Officer under the Administrative Control of the District Police Chief, Thiruvananthapuram city. A veterinary Hospital with a Veterinary Assistant Director and a Livestock Inspector for health care of the horses of this unit. Republic day parade, Independence Day Parade, Processions of Government, Law and order duties like Night Patrol duty, Morning and Evening Patrol duties etc are the main duties of this unit.

Title: Project KOOTTU - Child Safety Initiative by Kerala Police
Content: Project KOOTTU is a child safety initiative launched by the Kerala Police in collaboration with Bachpan Bachavo Andolan (BBA) to create a secure cyber space for children. The project was inaugurated by Shri. Pinarayi Vijayan, Hon. Chief Minister of Kerala, on 26-07-2022 at Government GHSS, Cotton Hill, Thiruvananthapuram. Its primary objective is to build comprehensive awareness among teenagers and develop infrastructure in districts across Kerala where P-Hunt cases are most prevalent. The initiative operates on two levels: Level 1 focuses on raising awareness among children, teachers, and parents regarding threats and challenges in cyberspace using modern IT techniques and robotics. Level 2 is dedicated to the rehabilitation of children who are victims of online crimes. As part of this effort, counseling centers and legal aid posts are being established in selected districts with high reports of P-Hunt cases. These services are provided free of cost and aim to support victims in overcoming all forms of exploitation.

Title: Law & Order Structure

These zones are subdivided into four Police Ranges: Thiruvananthapuram, Ernakulam, Thrissur, and Kannur, led by Deputy Inspectors General. Each range comprises three to five police districts, typically headed by Superintendents of Police. Exceptions include Thiruvananthapuram City, Kochi City, and Kozhikode City, which are headed by higher-ranked officers. There are a total of 19 police districts in Kerala, mostly aligned with revenue district boundaries except for five districts that are split into urban and rural units.

Title: Road Safety Tips for Pedestrians

Title: Garden Activities in KAP IV Battalion
Content: A garden committee is formed to promote agricultural activities of police personnel with the guidance of Andhoor Krishi Bhavan. Various types of crops, vegetables, and turmeric etc., have been cultivated using the manpower of the battalion. Vegetables so cultivated are distributed to company mess and to the family members and police personnel at an affordable rate. Garden fund account is maintained by Officer Commanding HQ Coy.

Title: Forensic Division
Content: The Kerala State Forensic Science Laboratory was established in 1961 in Thiruvananthapuram. Dr. Thangavelu, the then Principal of the Medical College, Thiruvananthapuram, was the first Honorary Director of the laboratory. At present, the laboratory consists of a Headquarters lab situated in Police Headquarters, Thiruvananthapuram, and two fully functional Regional Forensic Science Labs at Thrissur and Kannur respectively. There are 19 District Mobile Forensic Labs in all Police Districts. One new Regional FSL at Kochi has been commissioned and is about to start functioning. The Headquarters lab at Thiruvananthapuram has eleven divisions: Physics, Ballistics, Biology, Serology, DNA, Documents, Documents-Civil, Cyber, Chemistry, Explosives, and Polygraph. Forensic experts examine the scene of crime and material objects seized by investigators and submit their reports. They are called upon to give evidence relating to their findings in the court of law.

Title: Crime Branch Overview
Content: The Crime Branch, headed by ADGP Crimes, investigates complex, organized, and high-impact cases such as financial frauds, economic offences, and sensitive crimes. Cases are referred to the Crime Branch by the State Police Chief based on complexity and resource needs. It operates through three ranges—Thiruvananthapuram, Ernakulam, and Kozhikode—each managed by an Inspector General of Police. These ranges include district-level Crime Branch Units and Central Units led by Superintendents of Police.

Title: Background and Evolution of Sabarimala Queue Management
Content: Prior to the Sabarimala Pilgrim Management System (SPMS), the Kerala Police introduced the 'Sabarimala Virtual Q-System' in 2011–2012 to regulate queues at the shrine. This system allowed devotees to reserve a spot in a virtual line via the website www.sabarimalaq.com on a first-come-first-served basis. In 2019, the Hon’ble Chief Minister proposed a unified digital platform integrating police, devaswom, and transport services. TCS Hyderabad was engaged to develop SPMS, supported by technical teams from the ICT wing of Kerala Police, Devaswom, and KSRTC. The new portal (www.sabarimalaonline.org) was inaugurated on October 28, 2019. It offered 16.5 lakh virtual queue tickets across 15 time slots daily for 54 days. Devotees selecting this option avoided long physical queues and contributed to better crowd distribution.

Title: E-Challan System
Content: Kerala Police has initiated and commissioned a digital challan generation system for traffic violations. This E-Challan system enables traffic officers to generate electronic challans during traffic checks, streamlining the enforcement process.

Title: Crime Prevention Tips – House Theft
Content: Thefts are typically committed by young males seeking small, expensive items that can be quickly converted into cash. These crimes often occur in homes where residents are temporarily absent, happening both during the day and at night. Thieves usually select houses that are unoccupied, easily accessible, offer good cover, and have convenient escape routes. To prevent house theft, follow these steps: Keep doors locked and windows covered even during the daytime. Ensure all doors and windows are securely closed and locked before leaving. Install grills on windows and glass-paneled doors. Avoid walking alone at night. Inform neighbors of your absence and use lighting at exit points. Do not keep large amounts of cash or ornaments at home. Always identify visitors before opening the door. Never allow young children to open the door for strangers. Ask all representatives for proper identification.

Title: Counter Child Sexual Exploitation Centre (CCSE) - Kerala Police
Content: The Counter Child Sexual Exploitation Centre (CCSE) is a specialized unit under Kerala Police's Cyber Dome, established with the objective of preventing and combating online crimes against children, especially child pornography. It was constituted as part of Kerala Police’s 'Zero Tolerance' policy towards child exploitation and aligns with the 2019 focus on cybersecurity. The CCSE Centre serves as a center of excellence for tracing pedophiles and enhancing technological capabilities for effective policing. Its key functions include cyber intelligence, cyber security, incidence response, cyber safety awareness programs, and monitoring of darknet/VPNs. The unit collaborates closely with Interpol's Crimes Against Children unit and the International Centre for Missing and Exploited Children (ICMEC), utilizing Interpol-provided software to trace IP addresses even when encrypted communication methods are used. Awareness sessions are conducted for student police cadets, NSS volunteers, college students, resident associations, and government organizations.

Title: Unique Features of the Student Police Cadet (SPC) Project
Content: The unique features of the Student Police Cadet (SPC) Project include: An association between the educational and security frameworks of a state, that trains and encourages youth to develop respect for law and abiding by law as a way of life. Uses existing network, infrastructure and leadership qualities of Police to supplement the physical, mental and educational development of youth. Empowers school communities to create safe school environments and confident youth willing to act against social evils. Stimulates parents and community leaders to work with police in creating safer communities.

Title: NRI Cell
Content: The Cell is functioning in Police Headquarters, Thiruvananthapuram. The NRI Cell headed by a Superintendent of Police, is functioning under the direct supervision of ADGP Head quarters and IGP Head quarters. The NRI Cell handles exclusively the complaints of Non-Resident Keralites and their family members. The main function of the NRI Cell is to enquire into petitions relating to allegations of Visa cheating, fraudulent man power recruitment by agencies, trafficking of woman to other countries, especially Gulf, physical and mental harassment of NRIs at their overseas work places, etc. The petitions are received in this office directly from the aggrieved persons, through the Government of Kerala, other Government Authorities and State Police Chief. Non-Resident Keralites can file their complaints to the Kerala Police NRI Cell either by e-mail to spnri.pol@kerala.gov.in. Last updated on Thursday 18th of May 2023 PM

Title: POL-APP - Women and Child Services
Content: Under Women and Child Services, POL-APP provides Track My Trip, enabling users to share real-time location with three pre-registered contacts and send an SOS during emergencies. It also offers a feature to Fix an Appointment with the SHO for Women, allowing women to schedule meetings with the Station House Officer online.

Title: History of Kerala Police - Travancore State
Content: The Travancore State emerged in the mid-14th century. Prior to the 18th century, limited historical documentation exists about its police system. The region was divided into small kingdoms ruled by Desavazhis with Nattukootam assistance, lacking centralized governance. Under King Marthanda Varma (1729–1758), the need for an organized armed force arose. He employed the 'Marava Force' to suppress rebellions, taking over police duties. From 1757 AD, records show the kingdom’s division into administrative units with newly created posts like Sarvadhi-karyakar, Karyakar, and Pravarthyakar, responsible for law enforcement and judicial functions. Local authorities managed serious crimes like murder, robbery, and theft with community involvement.

Content: Motor Transport Wing SP (MT) is responsible for servicing/repairs/maintenance of vehicles of the department.
