The major repairs of the vehicles are taken up in the two range workshops, ie. at MSP workshop and Central workshop (SAP) which are headed by DySP (MT).

Title: Crime Branch, Kerala Police
Content: The Crime Branch is the specialized investigation wing of Kerala Police. It investigates cases assigned by the State Police Chief, the Government, or the High Court of Kerala. This includes sensational crimes, complicated and serious offences with statewide ramifications, and undetected cases. The Crime Branch serves as the Nodal agency for Interpol-related matters in the state and carries out verifications or enquiries on behalf of Interpol. It is headed by an officer holding the rank of Additional Director General of Police. For administrative purposes, the Crime Branch in Kerala is divided into three ranges, each under an Inspector General of Police, headquartered in Thiruvananthapuram, Ernakulam, and Kozhikode. These ranges are further subdivided into districts, each led by a Crime Branch Superintendent of Police. The branch specializes in investigating complex organized crimes, financial frauds, economic offences with significant impact, undetected or sensitive crime cases, and crimes with interstate connections. The Cyber Crime Police Station of Kerala Police and the Hi-Tech Crime Enquiry Cell also operate under the Crime Branch. Contact: Crime Branch Head Quarter, Crime Branch, Kerala. Phone: 0471-2722215. Email: adgpcb.pol@kerala.gov.in.

Title: Aims and Objectives of Child Friendly Police Stations (CFPS)
Content: The aims and objectives of Child Friendly Police Stations include: ensuring children grow up in a caring environment; prompt investigation of abuses; early identification and nurturing of at-risk children; raising awareness among parents, teachers, and society about children’s rights; making children conscious of their rights and duties; ensuring safe travel for children; preventing child labor and begging; creating accessible and just police stations for children and families; fostering partnerships between government, non-governmental agencies, and civil society; and building a protective community around every child involving parents, educators, and societal members.

Title: Kerala Armed Police - I (KAP I) Infrastructure and Locations
Content: The KAP I Battalion functions at the AR Camp, Tripunithura. The camp area is not specifically marked. One detachment camp of this Battalion operates at AR Camp, Kalamassery consisting of two companies, and another detachment camp consisting of one company is located at Pothanikkad. The offices of the Commandant, Deputy Commandant, Assistant Commandant (Adjt), Assistant Commandant (QM), AC I Wing, AC II Wing, and Battalion Office, along with most Company Commanders' offices except A, B, and E, are functioning in and around the New Battalion Administrative Block. The A and E company offices are currently located at the Detachment Camp, Kalamassery, and the B company office is at the Detachment Camp, Pothanikkad.

Title: State Industrial Security Force (SISF) - Overview
Content: The State Industrial Security Force (SISF) was formed to provide sufficient security cover to vital institutions, public sectors, and private sector banks in Kerala on a payment basis. It is a deputationist organization open only to officials of the police department. The SISF unit is functioning at Thiruvananthapuram, near the SAP Campus, Peroorkada.

Title: Kerala Armed Police 5 Battalion Overview
Content: The Kerala Armed Police 5 Battalion (KAP 5) was originally raised on 23/04/1983 as per Government Order (GO) MS 58/83 Home, with the objective of providing security to Hydro Electric Projects and other vital installations. On 20/03/1984, via GO (MS) 34/84 Home, it was officially named Kerala Police 5 Battalion, headquartered in Ernakulam. In 1984–85, the battalion was converted into the Armed Police Training Centre and then re-established as Kerala Armed Police 5 Battalion on 03/12/1990 through GO (MS) 163/90 Home. Currently, the battalion serves the districts of Kottayam and Idukki. The headquarters were relocated from Thrissur to Maniyar in Pathanamthitta District on 02/09/2003 to accommodate the Kerala Police Academy campus at Thrissur. Subsequently, orders were issued for shifting the battalion to Kuttikkanam in Idukki District, along with plans for constructing new barracks and quarters.

Title: Certificate of Non-Involvement in Offences (NIO Certificate) / Police Clearance Certificates (PCC)
Content: As per Department Circular No. 15/2022/PHQ dated 13/05/2022, the Police Clearance Certificates (PCC) previously issued under Section 59 of the Kerala Police Act, 2011 have been renamed as Certificate of Non-Involvement in Offences (NIO Certificate). These certificates are issued for job or other purposes within India. Applications for NIO Certificate can be submitted either online or offline. Online applications can be made via the THUNA portal (https://thuna.keralapolice.gov.in/) or through the Kerala Police mobile app 'Pol-APP'. Offline applications may be submitted directly at the respective District Police Office or Police Station. In both cases, the application will be processed through the iCoPS system. An acknowledgement receipt is generated based on the mode of submission. Required details include personal information, contact information, identification details, current and permanent addresses (or last residence in Kerala if both are outside the state), authorized contact person details (if applicable), criminal record disclosure (via affidavit if any), and purpose of the certificate. Documents required include a passport-sized photograph, proof of address (such as Ration Card, Voter’s ID, SSLC Book, Aadhaar Card, or Passport), proof of identity (Government‑issued ID, Aadhaar Card, Voter’s ID, Driving License, or Passport), and documentation indicating the need for the certificate (e.g., job advertisement or request letter). Fees amount to Rs. 700/‑, payable online for digital submissions or through challan/TR 5 for offline applications. Upon verification, the certificate will be issued with a QR code and applicant's photo; scanning the QR code verifies authenticity. Rejected applications receive formal notices accordingly.

Title: History of Kerala Police - Ancient Period
Content: The history of policing in ancient Kerala is derived from literary works of the Sangham period (200 AD), such as Akamkrithikal, Pathittipattu, and Chilppathikaram. These texts describe the appointment of sentries and watchmen to protect travelers and merchant caravans. A special group conducted investigations, as detailed in Chilappathikaram. Various roles included Charan, Doothan, Apasarpakan, and Goodapurushan in secret service. Types of guards mentioned include Kaval (guards), Kanchukil (uniformed officers), Harrikaran (officers with designated duties), Souvidithon (court duty attendants), Vetradharan (king's bodyguards), Dwarapalakas (gate guards), Darsaka or Prathihara (personal assistants to the king), and Kolkaran (stick-armed men). The feudal system under the Cheras involved Thara, Desom, and Nadu, governed by Madampi, Desavazhi, and Naduvazhi respectively, who enforced laws and administered punishments.

2. Kerala Police Officers Association – Comprises Assistant Sub-Inspectors up to Circle Inspectors.
3. Kerala Police Officers Association (Senior Ranks) – Consists of Deputy Superintendents and Superintendents of Police (Non-IPS).

These organizations focus on grievance redressal, better service conditions, coordination of welfare measures, and fostering community relations. A monthly magazine published by the Kerala Police Association is widely read among its members.

Title: Subhayathra Project Overview
Content: The Subhayathra Project was launched by the Government of Kerala and Kerala Police to address the escalating road accident rates in the state. With nearly 4,000 deaths and around 35,000 injuries occurring annually, the project focuses on improving traffic safety through a comprehensive approach targeting the 'Three E's': Enforcement, Engineering, and Education. It emphasizes a multi-faceted and coordinated effort involving all sections of society to make Kerala’s roads safer for everyone.

Title: Cyberdome Initiative by Kerala Police
Content: Cyberdome is a centre for excellence in cyber security, established by Kerala Police as a public-private partnership initiative. It aims to bridge the gap between evolving cyber innovations and the skill sets of law enforcement to combat emerging cyber threats. The initiative serves as a collaborative platform for public and private stakeholders to share information and resources to enhance cybersecurity. It includes an online office of technical experts, ethical hackers, and cyber professionals who assist the police in cybersecurity and cyber crime investigations. These professionals are known as 'Cyberdome Volunteers'. Kerala Police organizes events such as KID GLOVE to highlight child protection in cyberspace and conducts an annual international cybersecurity and policing conference named c0c0n, which has gained global recognition. For more information, visit the Kerala Police Cyberdome. Reference: G.O (Ms.) No.167/2014/Home dated 22/08/2014. Last updated on Monday, 3rd April 2023 PM.

Title: Photographic Bureau - Functions and Responsibilities
Content: The Photographic Bureau in Kerala is attached to the Police Headquarters and is headed by the Chief Photographer. It has units operating in all District and City Police Offices, as well as at the Forensic Science Laboratory (FSL) and CBCID headquarters. Following amendments to Section 65-B of the Indian Evidence Act-1872, photographs and video recordings are admissible as documentary evidence under Section 9 of the same act. Only photographers from the Police Department are authorized to capture images intended for use as legal evidence. Section 45 of the Indian Evidence Act recognizes photographers as subject experts. The bureau operates on a round-the-clock basis, ensuring staff availability for both routine and emergency tasks involving the documentation of scenes of crime, forensic evidence such as fingerprints, hair, and blood stains, and processes like inquests in unnatural death cases. Additionally, they record functions conducted under the police department’s authority, statements under Section 164 CrPC, post-mortem examinations in police custody or jail deaths, exhumations, polygraph tests, recoveries under Section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act, law and order situations, provocative speeches, court proceedings involving deaf/dumb victims, confessions by accused persons, and visits by VVIPs/VIPs/PPs.

Title: Crime and Criminal Tracking Network & Systems (CCTNS) Overview
Content: The Crime and Criminal Tracking Network & Systems (CCTNS) is a Mission Mode Project (MMP) under the National e-Governance Plan of the Government of India. Its objective is to create a comprehensive and integrated system for enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness of policing. CCTNS automates police functions at both police station and higher levels and provides public services such as online complaint registration, case status tracking, and person verification. The system facilitates the collection, storage, retrieval, analysis, transfer, and sharing of data and information among police stations, State Headquarters, and Central Police Organizations. The National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) serves as the central nodal agency managing CCTNS.

Title: About Kerala Police
Content: Kerala State Police is the law enforcement agency for the State of Kerala with its Headquarters at Thiruvananthapuram, the State Capital. Kerala Police has a reputation for being one of the best-managed state police forces in the country and is one of the top-ranking states in terms of maintenance of law and order. Kerala Police is also one of the first Police departments in South Asia to implement community policing through an enactment. It is popularly known as 'Janamaithri' Policing, which literally translates to people-friendly Policing. Kerala Police registers the highest number of cognizable offences in the country, next only to the National Capital Territory of Delhi. This has to be viewed in perspective of the relatively peaceful image of the state. This is a reflection of the good practice adopted by the state in registering every cognizable instance reported at the Police station level and dealing with the crimes and offenders legally. Kerala Police has been the fountain head of several police reforms and innovative schemes in the country. A new Kerala Police Act enacted in 2011 was a guiding light for many other state police forces in the country to draft their own local Police Acts. The avant-garde provisions of the Act, which enable setting up of Police Establishment Board, Police Complaints Authority, State Security Commission, Police Welfare Bureau, Community Policing, etc., have given it a status of a modern day treatise on Policing philosophy.

Title: About Kerala Police
Content: Student Police Cadet Scheme piloted by the Kerala state during 2008-2010, to positively tackle adolescent deviant behavior and encourage good citizenship values among youth has been endorsed as a plan scheme by Ministry of Home Affairs and has now been adopted by many other states in India. Similarly, initiatives as such as Kerala Police Cyberdome, a PPP model in cyber governance and Kerala Police CoCoN, a flagship annual conference on cyber security and digital strategies to tackle crimes, have earned a respectable place in the hearts of all stakeholders. The high literacy levels in Kerala society are also reflected in the high levels of educational qualification among the cutting edge level police officials of Kerala Police. Their demeanour, turn-out and skill levels in dealing with citizens, mirror their education levels. The recruitment of constabulary level officials done through a stringent competitive exam by an independent Public Service Commission echoes the ethos of Kerala society for transparency and fairness. The newly recruited Police officials are trained in the latest police subjects, both indoor and outdoor, and nurtured to live up to the motto of Kerala Police.

Title: Merger of India Reserve Battalion and Controversy in 1968
Content: Maintaining both the India Reserve Battalion and the SAP in the same region caused administrative challenges. Therefore, the Government of India decided to merge the India Reserve Battalion with the Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) to ensure functional uniformity. In January 1967, the dissolution process was completed. The State Government proposed merging senior police officers into the first Battalion of the SAP and allowing the rest to join the CRPF if they wished. Those unwilling to join either force were to be dismissed upon returning from Nagaland. However, 897 out of 971 members disagreed with this decision. Directly recruited officers claimed they had definitive appointment orders to the Kerala Police and refused to join the CRPF. Tensions escalated in May 1968 when A-Company refused deployment to Bible Hill, leading to exemption from duties. The entire battalion engaged in protest actions. Disciplinary measures were initiated, and by September 1968, actions against 694 personnel were finalized. Dismissed members staged a 'Satyagraha' at the Secretariat and approached courts without success. Eventually, most were re-employed in various government departments based on their educational qualifications due to a humanitarian stance by the Government.

Title: Women Self Defence Training Program - Kerala Police
Content: The Women Self Defence Training Program is a unique initiative of Kerala Police under its Community Policing Project. This project aims at empowering women through comprehensive awareness and practical training programs. The vulnerability of women and young girls is a major factor contributing to the instances of crime against women. This special programme for women's self-defense has become extremely popular among the women folk of Kerala. No agency in India had previously undertaken hands-on WSDT training on such a large scale; when completed, it set a national record. A total of 1,22,210 women were trained by the women self-defense trainers across the state from November 2018 to February 2019. The highest number of trainees were from Kochi City, while the lowest numbers were from Kozhikode Rural. The WSDT trainers conducted sessions in 503 schools throughout the state. Around 67 schools in Idukki and 52 schools in Thiruvananthapuram Rural participated in the program. In total, 80,470 students and others in various schools received training. Eleven colleges each in Thiruvananthapuram City and Thrissur City also took part, with 3,245 college students trained in these cities along with Kasaragod. Additionally, 26,675 individuals were trained through classes held at 212 different institutions across the state. Alappuzha recorded the highest number of training programs in residential areas and institutions (39). Kochi City and Kasaragod led in terms of the number of women trained in self-defense techniques. A combined total of 39,834 women were trained in Thiruvananthapuram Rural, Kochi City, and Idukki Districts.

Title: Kerala Armed Police - III Battalion History and Contact Details
Content: The Kerala Armed Police - III (KAP 3) Battalion was initially formed with its headquarters at Nilambur as per Government Order (GO) (MS) No: 22/03/1979. The headquarters were later moved to Thiruvananthapuram as per GO (MS) No. 119/79/Home dated 31.08.1979. In 1983, the headquarters were shifted to Alappuzha as per GO (MS) No. 38/83/Home dated 16.03.1983. However, since the land intended for acquisition in Alappuzha town was repurposed for constructing Police Quarters for the District Police, the government relocated the battalion headquarters to Cherthala, acquiring necessary land as per GO (MS) No. 50/85/Home dated 02.03.1985. From Thiruvananthapuram, the battalion was temporarily shifted to Pandikkadu in Malappuram District, where it operated until February 1988. In March 1988, the battalion headquarters were moved to the SAP Campus in Thiruvananthapuram via GO (Rt.) No. 343/Home dated 27.01.1988. As per GO (Rt) No: 384/91/Home dated 17.01.1991, the government ordered the permanent establishment of the battalion headquarters at Adoor in Pathanamthitta District. A total of 14.1650 hectares of land in Old Survey No: 267 (part) and 308 (New Survey No: 52 & 48/03) in Erathu Village (Erathu Panchayath), Adoor Taluk, previously owned by Sri K. Damodaran Unnithan, was acquired for Rs. 87,63,953/-. The foundation stone for the new campus was laid by then Hon'ble Chief Minister of Kerala, Sri E.K. Nayanar, on 29.08.1998. Construction of the buildings was handled by the Kerala Police Housing Construction Corporation.

Title: Road Safety Tips for Two-Wheeler Riders
Content: Wearing a helmet significantly reduces the risk of head injuries. Studies show that only 24% of helmeted riders sustained head injuries compared to 56% without helmets. Neurological deficiencies occurred in 14% of helmeted riders versus 33% among unhelmeted ones. Helmets also reduce the force and torque on the neck during impacts and decrease dynamic head impact by 50%. When approaching uncontrolled junctions, ask yourself: Am I coming from a minor road to a major road? Can other drivers see me? Do I have an escape route? At controlled or signalized junctions, consider: Is the green light about to change? Do I have enough time to stop? Can the vehicle behind me stop safely? Before taking a bend or turn, check: How sharp is the curve? Is the sight distance sufficient? Is my speed appropriate? While overtaking, ensure: Is the vehicle ahead turning right? Is there adequate sight distance? Is there a fast-approaching vehicle on the right? If being overtaken, reflect: Am I uncomfortable with this maneuver? Have I signaled properly? Are multiple vehicles overtaking simultaneously? When passing parked vehicles, watch out for: Sudden opening of doors, pedestrians rushing out, or vehicles pulling out unexpectedly. Regarding positioning, always ask: Can I see and be seen clearly? Is traffic limiting my options? Is there enough space to stop safely?

Title: Kerala Police Training Structure and Institutions
Content: Police training in Kerala is overseen by the Additional Director General of Police (Training) and the Director of the Kerala Police Academy. The Police Training College in Thiruvananthapuram is responsible for the training of IPS officers after their initial training at the National Police Academy, Hyderabad, as well as probationary Deputy Superintendents of Police (Dy.SP) and probationary Sub-Inspectors (SI). It also provides training for Head Constables promoted to the ranks of Assistant Sub-Inspector (ASI) and SI. In-service, reorientation, and capsule courses are conducted for officers of and above the rank of SI at this institution. Constable induction training is delivered through the Armed Police Battalions over a period of 9 months. The induction training duration for SIs at the Police Training College is one year. Upon joining the state, IPS officer trainees undergo instruction in Police Standing Orders, Special and Local Acts, Treasury Code, and related subjects at the Police Training College in Thiruvananthapuram.

Title: Police Integration in Travancore-Cochin State
Content: Travancore-Cochin State formed on July 1, 1949. Despite similar setups, minor differences existed in station house officer systems. Post-merger with the Indian Union, the state force lost independence, integrating into Union Forces deployable nationwide. Internal security shifted to the Union Armed Reserved Force. Recruitment for senior positions began routing through UPSC after its establishment in 1950. In 1951, UPSC representatives selected N. Chandrasekharan Nair, M. Gopalan, Srinivasa Iyer, K. Sreenivasa Rao, M. Krishna Pillai, and T K Bhaskara Marar for the Indian Police Service cadre under Madras State.

Title: Cyber Security Guidelines and Phishing Awareness
Content: Phishing involves fraudulent emails, web pages, and text messages designed to steal personal and financial information for identity theft. Users often receive deceptive messages appearing to originate from legitimate businesses. To protect against phishing, verify the legitimacy of websites and emails before providing sensitive data. Shield your PIN when using ATMs or point-of-sale terminals. Never let your debit or credit card out of sight during transactions. Always collect your card and transaction receipt after completing a purchase. Ensure online shopping sites are secure by checking for HTTPS URLs and padlock symbols. Log off or close the browser completely after online purchases. Report lost or stolen cards immediately to your financial institution to minimize misuse.

Title: Pink Police Patrol Initiative by Kerala Police
Content: Kerala Police introduced 'Pink Beat' patrols to enhance the safety of women and children in public places. These patrols include specially trained women police personnel who patrol on KSRTC and private stage carriers and are present at bus stops, schools, colleges, and other public places. The Pink Patrol cars are equipped with GPS tracking devices and cameras installed on the front and rear sides, which send continuous visuals to the control room. Each patrol vehicle is led by a woman police officer and includes two other women police personnel. The patrol operates from 8 am to 8 pm in areas with a high presence of women. Personnel monitor crowded public buses for misuse and harassment and look out for anti-social activities at bus stops, schools, and other vulnerable areas. The initiative was first launched in Thiruvananthapuram, Ernakulam, and Kozhikode City, with plans to extend it to other parts of the state. The primary objective is to prevent atrocities and crimes against women and children, ensuring their safety and creating a sense of security. The Pink Police Patrol Help Line Number is 1515.

Title: CAP House - State Resource Centre of Children and Police
Content: CAP House is a state-level resource center established by the Kerala Police to ensure a safe, protective, and nurturing environment for children. It serves as a hub for coordinating and implementing child-related initiatives such as the Student Police Cadets Program (SPC), Our Responsibility to Children (ORC), Project Hope, and Child Friendly Police Stations (CFPS). CAP House functions as a call center offering support to CAP functionaries and the general public. It provides guidance on investigating POCSO and other child-related cases, connects experts like psychologists, child psychiatrists, legal consultants, and pediatricians, and offers information on shelter homes, care institutions, and counseling centers. The center also encourages reporting of crimes against children and assists with procedures like FIR registration. CAP House facilitates collaboration between the Kerala Police and the Women and Child Development Department to strengthen mutual interventions. Last updated on Tuesday, 9th May 2023 PM.

Title: About Pol-App - Official Mobile App of Kerala Police
Content: Pol-App is the official mobile application of the Kerala Police, inaugurated by the Hon. Chief Minister of Kerala on June 10, 2020. As of April 20, 2021, the app had been downloaded by approximately 290,254 users and is considered one of the most popular police apps in India. Title: Integrated Administrative Processing System (iAPS) - Kerala Police
Content: iAPS is a web-based application designed for use in the Administrative Offices of the Police Department. Its primary objective is to enhance transparency within the department, both for the public and police personnel. The software is under development by the Kerala State IT Mission. The project was sanctioned under State Plan Projects for the year 2010-2011 as per GO(Rt) No. 2178/2010/Home dated 30/06/2010. It has been implemented across the department through the State Crime Record Bureau (SCRB), Thiruvananthapuram. The Director General of Police, SCRB, Thiruvananthapuram, serves as the Nodal Officer for this project.

Title: Submission of Photographs as Legal Evidence
Content: Photographs submitted as evidence must be printed without alterations to the original file. A CD containing the original image files must accompany the physical prints, clearly labeled with markings identifying each photo's corresponding digital file. Photos should be printed on 12x8-inch paper, with the original image-file number marked adjacent to or beneath each print. Each photograph must carry a serial number. A detailed certificate under Section 65-B of the Indian Evidence Act-1872 must be included, specifying the crime number, date of exposure, total number of photographs, page numbers where they appear, and details of devices used. This certificate must bear the office seal and a copy retained in the photographer's office. Delivery details must be logged in the duty register. Pages of printed photographs must indicate their sequence, e.g., 'page 1 of 5'.

Title: Functions of the State Finger Print Bureau
Content: The main functions of the State Finger Print Bureau include: recording fingerprint slips of convicted persons across Kerala; verifying previous convictions of arrested individuals throughout the state; conducting O.V. searches to locate ex-convicts; identifying unidentified dead bodies; and performing document comparisons involving thumb impressions in both criminal and civil cases, using documents received from courts, registration departments, post offices, and others.

Title: Tourism Police
Content: The scenic beauty and vibrant traditions of Kerala have long made it a coveted tourist destination with both domestic and international tourists. A separate wing of the police called the tourism police has been created particularly to cater to the needs of tourists. Such tourist police are handpicked and trained to interact with tourists and are on many occasions able to speak multiple languages including Tamil, Hindi, English and French apart from Malayalam.

Kodiyeri Balakrishnan, the then Home Minister of Kerala State, on 11th June 2006, in the presence of Sri. Raman Sri Vasthava IPS, Director General of Police, Kerala. After a new guest house was constructed at the PTC in 2019, the PT Com building was refurbished to function as 'Sadbhavana', a transition house for senior officers. Additionally, Sadbhavana also functions as a Domestic Conflict Resolution Centre. Last updated on Saturday, 5th February 2022.

Title: About Kerala Police
Content: Kerala Police is headed by the State Police Chief, who is the senior most Indian Police Service officer in the State and holds the rank of Director General of Police. The State Police Chief is designated as the Head of the department for all administrative and operational purposes. The police force is assisted by officers and subject domain experts across the state for effective administration.

Title: Crime Records Bureau
Content: A Crime Records Bureau functions as a sub-unit of the Railway Police Headquarters, located within the same compound. It is supervised by a DYSP and is responsible for communicating crime-related information within the Kerala Railway Police unit to entities such as the State Crime Records Bureau (SCRB), SSB Headquarters, RPF, and the Railway Board.
